title: 108_hr818
content: The Act is titled the "Identity Theft Consumer Notification Act" and requires financial institutions to promptly notify and assist customers whose personal information is compromised. The Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act is amended to include a requirement for financial institutions to promptly notify customers if their personal information is compromised. The financial institution must notify customers promptly of any compromise of their personal information and provide assistance to remedy the situation, including reimbursing the consumer for any losses incurred. Financial institutions are required to promptly notify customers of any compromise of their personal information and provide assistance to remedy the situation. Additionally, a financial institution may delay notifying a consumer of a security breach at the request of a law enforcement agency for a limited time determined by the agency. Penalties for Failure To Notify and Assist Customers After Identity Theft: Financial institutions must promptly notify consumers of any compromise of their personal information and provide assistance. Failure to do so will be considered a violation. Failure to comply with subsection (b)(5)(C) will be considered a violation of enforcement actions under section 505 and the requirements of section 623(a)(2) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act. SEC. 3. ADDITIONAL PROTECTION FOR VICTIMS OF IDENTITY THEFT. Amends Section 618 of the Fair Credit Reporting Act to address jurisdiction of courts and limitations of actions. SEC. 618 of the Fair Credit Reporting Act allows actions to enforce liabilities in any US district court within 2 years of discovery. The limitations period is tolled if a defendant willfully misrepresents material information required to be disclosed.
